ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Enhancing surface plasmon polariton propagation by two-layer dielectric-loaded waveguides on silver surface

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We report a study of a two-layer dielectric-loaded surface plasmon polariton waveguide (TDLSPPW) which consisted of two dielectric layers (high-index/low-index) on a silver film. The discontinuity of the electric field at the interfaces resulted in a concentrated field in the low-index region. It efficiently reduced the propagation loss of the surface plasmon polariton mode. The mode fields and corresponding complex propagation constants were calculated by a vector finite-difference method. The propagation properties were measured by a modified near-field optical microscope. It is confirmed that the propagation length of the proposed TDLSPPW was about 1.6 times longer than conventional single-layer SPP waveguides. In addition, a 90∘ waveguide turn with 3 μm radius showed that the bending loss was smaller than 2 dB.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: A surface plasmon polariton (SPP) is an electromagnetic wave propagating along a metal–dielectric interface with advantages of subwavelength size and strong optical confinement. It has been proposed to be applied for ultra-high-density photonic integrated circuits [1–4]. Several passive nanophotonic elements such as directional couplers [5, 6], ring resonators [7, 8], photonic Bragg reflectors as well as optically integrated waveguide modulators [9–11] have been developed. There are several SPP waveguides providing efficient guiding of waves beyond the diffraction limit, such as nanowires [12], nanoparticles [13], V-grooves [14] and dielectric-loaded waveguides [15, 16]. Although those SPP waveguides possess strong optical confinement, a demand for decreasing the ohmic loss in the metal film is necessary in order to increase the propagation length. A way to increase the propagation length is to use a very thin metallic film in a dielectric core [17, 18]. It substantially increases not only the mode size but also the bending loss. There is always a trade-off between the propagation length and the mode confinement [19]. Recently, some nanowire configurations for guiding SPP and cylinder modes called hybrid plasmonic waveguides were reported [20, 21]. The SPP mode can be confined in the gap between nanowire and substrate. It simultaneously improves the propagation length and the mode confinement. However, this configuration is not easy to be fabricated by using a top-down process. Besides, most works were focused on simulations.

In this work, we propose a hybrid waveguide design, i.e. a two-layer dielectric-loaded surface plasmon polariton waveguide (TDLSPPW). The TDLSPPW is made of two refractive-index layers on a silver thin film with a high-index/low-index/metal configuration. We theoretically study SPP propagation properties and experimentally confirm the improvement by using a near-field coupling method combined with surface plasmon leakage radiation optical microscopy [22, 23] in visible to infrared wavelengths.

Section1.Heading: Device modeling and calculations
Section1.Para:
The eigenmodes and eigenvalues (propagation constants) of the waveguides were calculated by using a vector finite-difference modesolver [24]. The beam propagation of the SPP was simulated by using the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method (FullWave 6.1, Rsoft). Figure 1 shows the layouts for the DLSPPW and the TDLSPPW. The index of the dielectric of the DLSPPW is n with a thickness h and a width w. For the TDLSPPW, the high-index dielectric part has a refractive index n 1 and a thickness t 1 and the low-index part has a refractive index n 2 and a thickness t 2. Both dielectric waveguides are located on a silver film with semi-infinite thickness. The wavelength-dependent refractive index of silver, n 3, was obtained from the reported literature [25].
Fig. 1
The layout for the two different dielectric waveguides. (a) The conventional dielectric-loaded SPP waveguide. (b) The modified dielectric waveguide. A high-index (n 1) region is on the top; a low index (n 2) region is placed between the silver film and the high-index region

In the calculations, we first determine the eigenmodes for a TM wave under different conditions. Figure 2 shows the real part and the imaginary part of the complex effective refractive index (n eff). n is 1.5, w is 300 nm and the incident wavelength is 0.65 μm. The waveguide is single mode when h is smaller 300 nm. The corresponding propagation length is defined by [26]
1
$$ L= \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\times \operatorname{Im}( n_{\mathrm{eff}} )}. $$ The length is smaller than 10 μm. As can be seen in the mode distribution, the TM00 field is localized on the metallic surface. The strong ohmic loss results in a large propagation loss of the fundamental SPP mode. For the first-order mode (TM01), 300 nm<h<570 nm, most of the optical field is located in the dielectric core. The ohmic loss is greatly reduced. In the case of h=500 nm, the propagation length is increased to 52 μm, five times longer than the fundamental mode. With a further increase of waveguide height, 570 nm<h<800 nm, three modes exist in the waveguide. It is noted that the lowest propagation loss occurs in the TM01 mode. The higher order mode does not have a lower loss. We attribute the low propagation loss of the TM01 mode to a concentrated field in the dielectric core, as seen in the mode patterns of Fig. 2b.
Fig. 2
The calculated complex effective refractive index in the monolayer dielectric-loaded SPP waveguide for different dielectric thicknesses. (a) The real part of the effective refractive index. (b) The imaginary part. The insets show optical distributions of three different TM modes

The optical distribution plays an important part in the propagation loss. For the fundamental mode, the DLSPPW has its maximum field at the metal/dielectric interface. Increasing the height or width will not reduce the loss of the TM00 mode. The increase of height or width will also increase the mode number and form multi-mode waveguides. In most waveguide devices, such as modulators and wavelength splitters, the single-mode condition is necessary. Therefore, with the current DLSPPW layout, it is impossible to increase the propagation length by varying only the dimensions. For conventional waveguides, it is known that the guiding wave distribution can be adjusted by varying the index distribution of the waveguide core. In our proposed TDLSPPW, we design two indexes in the core. Figure 3a shows the real part and the imaginary part of the effective refractive index for n 1=2.06 with t 1 thickness and n 2=1.35 with t 2 thickness. For the single-mode condition, we set h=t 1+t 2=300 nm and w=130 nm. The ratio,
$R = \frac{t_{1}}{ t_{1} + t_{2}}$ , indicates the averaged core index changing from high index to low index. The real part of the effective refractive index, Re(n eff), increases with the increase of core index. Nevertheless, the imaginary part (the loss part) has a minimum value at R=0.7. The loss is even smaller than the waveguide with a single low-index layer, which has weak optical confinement.
Fig. 3
(a) The calculated complex effective refractive index as a function of percentage of the low-index region in the total dielectric region. The inset shows the cross-sectional view of the TDLSPPW. The fundamental mode (TM00) of a 300-nm-thick and 130-nm-width waveguide: (b) TDLSPPW and (c) DLSPPW

The reduction of optical absorption can be realized by the eigenmode distribution in the TDLSPPW. Figures 3b and 3c show the eigenmodes (E
y ) for the TDLSPPW (n 1=2.06, n 2=1.35, t 1=t 2=150 nm) and the DLSPPW (n=1.64, h=300 nm), respectively. The DLSPPW has a typical evanescent distribution which exponentially decays along the height direction. The maximum intensity is at the dielectric/silver interface. Therefore, the ohmic loss is large. On the other hand, the eigenmode in the TDLSPPW is concentrated in the low-index region due to the boundary condition effect of the TM mode. From the electromagnetic wave theory, D=εE must be continued at the interface for the TM wave. It results in
$E_{2} (y= t_{2} )= \frac{n_{1}^{2}}{n_{2}^{2}} E_{1}$ and
$E_{2} (y=0)= \frac{n_{3}^{2}}{n_{2}^{2}} E_{3}$ . Because n 2≪n 1 and |n 3|, the E 2 field in the low-index region has an enlarged field at both interfaces. Since t 1 has a subwavelength thickness, the evanescent tails of both enlarged fields will overlapand thus store a strong field in the low-index region. As can be seen from Fig. 3b, the optical field shows a step-like distribution in the low-index region. Because the optical wave is localized in the dielectric region, the TDLSPPW can decrease the ohmic loss from the metal film and provide a better confinement for the SPP wave.

Such two-layer index structure can be applied at different wavelengths to reduce the propagation loss. It is interesting to compare the wavelength-dependent propagation properties for both DLSPPW and TDLSPPW. Figures 4a and 4b show the calculated
$\operatorname{Re}(n_{\mathrm{eff}})$ and propagation length for monolayer and two-layer SPP waveguides. The propagation length is calculated by Eq. (1). In the calculations, w=130 nm, h=300 nm for DLSPPW, t 1=t 2=150 nm for TDLSPPW. Different core refractive indexes are considered for the DLSPPW. The wavelength ranges from 600 nm to 1600 nm. The propagation length increases with the wavelength. On the other hand, the propagation index decreases with the wavelength. The higher the refractive index of the dielectric layer, the higher the
$\operatorname{Re}(n_{\mathrm{eff}})$ of the SPP waveguide. It is noted that TDLSPPW (n 1=2.06, n 2=1.35 and t 1=t 2=150 nm, black line) has a similar
$\operatorname{Re}(n_{\mathrm{eff}})$ to DLSPPW (n 1=1.5, n 2=1.5 and t=300 nm, red line). However, their propagation lengths (L) are quite different. For the TDLSPPW, the length is longer than the DLSPPW over all the wavelength region. In the case of 800 nm wavelength, the propagation length of the TDLSPPW is about 1.67 times longer than the DLSPPW.
Fig. 4
(a) The real part of the effective refractive index of the TM00 mode as a function of wavelength. (b) The calculated propagation length as a function of wavelength for different waveguides

Section1.Heading: Fabrication and measurements
Section1.Para:
To verify the propagation properties of the proposed TDLSPPW and DLSPPW, we fabricated SPP waveguides with different bending radii, as shown in Fig. 5. The single-mode waveguide consisted of a 130-nm-width and 300-nm-thick dielectric on a 75-nm-thick silver film. The silver film was coated on cover glass slides by an electron gun evaporator. The dielectric waveguides were made by using electron beam lithography and a lift-off method. For TDLSPPW, the waveguide patterns were defined by electron beam exposure to a 400-nm-thick polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) layer spin coated on the glass substrate. A 150-nm-thick MgF2 layer (n 2=1.35) and a 150-nm MoO3 layer (n 1=2.06) were deposited by a thermal evaporator. The TDLSPPWs were formed after removing the PMMA by acetone. We also made DLSPPWs for comparison. The DLSPPWs were fabricated by spin casting a 300-nm-thick negative photoresist (ma-N 2403 series, Micro Resist Technology) on the silver film. The ma-N formed a transparent dielectric film with a refractive index of 1.56. The waveguide structures were directly made by electron beam lithography.
Fig. 5
The fabrication flow charts for both DLSPPW and TDLSPPW. (a) The fabrication of DLSPPW. Negative transparent electroresist, ma-N 2403, is used as the dielectric; the pattern is defined by the electron-beam lithographic method. (b) The fabrication of TDLSPPW. The waveguide core is formed by depositing two different dielectric materials. The scanning electron microscope images show the waveguide patterns made by both methods

In the experiments, we used a near-field coupling method [27, 28] combined with leakage radiation microscopy to measure the propagation properties of SPP modes. Figure 6a shows the measurement setup. A transmission-mode scanning near-field optical setup was mounted on an inverted optical microscope (Olympus IX71). The light source was a supercontinuum white light which was combined with a monochromator to select the output wavelength. The light was coupled into a tapered optical fiber probe and linearly polarized in the x-direction. The fiber probe had a tip diameter of about 80 nm. It was made by a modified wet-etching method [29] followed by the deposition of 100-nm-thick aluminum around the tip. The probe–sample distance was regulated by using a tuning-fork-based shear-force-feedback system [30]. The evanescent wave at the probe tip excited the SPP wave [28] at the silver/air interface and coupled into the waveguide. Because
$\operatorname{Re}(n_{\mathrm{eff}})$ of the SPP mode was smaller than the index of the glass substrate (n
b =1.46) and the silver film had a finite thickness (75 nm), the SPP mode leaked a small portion of light into the substrate. We used an oil immersion lens with a high numerical aperture (NA=1.45) larger than
$\operatorname{Re}(n_{\mathrm{eff}})$ to collect the leakage light. The leakage radiation from the waveguide was imaged by charge-coupled devices (Pixelfly VGA for visible to near-infrared light and Xenics Xeva for infrared light).
Fig. 6
(a) Experimental setup of near-field excitation and leakage radiation microscopy. The SPP was excited by the evanescent wave from the tapered fiber probe. The probe–sample distance was regulated by the tuning-fork-feedback method. Leakage radiation was imaged by a CCD camera. Leakage radiation images of DLSPPWs with waveguide thicknesses (b) 350 nm and (c) 670 nm. (d) FDTD simulation of the longitudinal mode in the DLSPPW with h=600 nm. White arrows show the leakage radiation through the silver film into the substrate

The intensity of the leakage radiation was proportional to the intensity in the waveguide. Therefore, we can compare the propagation loss and bending loss directly from the images. Figures 6b and 6c show the leakage radiation images of DLSPPW measured at 650 nm wavelength. The bright spot in the image was the near-field source from the fiber probe. For a waveguide height of about 350 nm, we obtained a single mode pattern. The propagation length estimated from the image is about 25 μm. For a waveguide height of 670 nm, a beating pattern was measured. The pattern resulted from the interference of two propagation modes with different propagation constants. From Fig. 2, there are three modes (TM00, TM01, TM02) existing in this waveguide (h=670 nm). The TM00 mode has a large absorption loss; it would not contribute to the beating pattern after tens of microns propagation. On the other hand, the TM01 and TM02 modes have a similar propagation length which is much longer than that of TM00. Therefore, this beating pattern results from the interference of both TM01 and TM02 modes. To further confirm the beating pattern, we simulated the propagation of 650-nm-wavelength light along the DLSPPW using the FDTD method. Figure 6d shows the simulated pattern in the x–z plane (side view). The optical field shows a periodic oscillation. When it touches the silver film, a small portion of the guiding wave leaks out. In the leakage radiation optical microscope, the leakage light shows a beating pattern in the x–y plane. The period in the measured image is 2.2 μm, which is consistent with the period (2.1 μm) in the FDTD image.

In the DLSPPW, the fundamental TM00 mode has a short propagation length. As indicated from the vector finite-difference calculations, the absorption loss of the TM00 mode can be improved by using the two-layer layout. To verify the improvement, we measured TDLSPPW and DLSPPW with the same waveguide size, w=180 nm, h=t 1+t 2=300 nm. It is noted that we used a 130-nm width for all SPP waveguides. In the experiments, the width of the fabricated pattern was 180 nm due to the inaccuracy of the e-beam writing and lift-off processes. The inset of Fig. 7a shows typical images of both waveguides. Apparently, the TM00 mode has a longer propagation length in TDLSPPW. We obtained the propagation length of the SPP mode by an exponential fitting of the intensity profile along the waveguide direction. The fitted propagation lengths for different excited wavelengths for TDLSPPWs and DLSPPWs are shown in Fig. 7b. The measured propagation lengths of both TM00 modes show consistent results with the calculations in Fig. 4b. The propagation length of TDLSPPWs is about 1.6 times longer than DLSPPWs from the visible to the infrared regions. It is noted that the TDLSPPW does not only enhance the propagation length but also provides a stronger optical confinement than the conventional DLSPPW, as seen in Fig. 3b. The confinement would provide a good guiding ability. To study the guiding effect, we fabricated 90∘ waveguide turns with different bending radii r from 0.25 μm to 5 μm with a waveguide width of 130 nm. The insets in Fig. 7c show the leakage radiation images of the waveguide turns. The bending loss decreases with the increase of bending radius. For the waveguide bend with a small radius of 1 μm, we find an apparent bending of the SPP wave. The bending loss is smaller than 2 dB when the radius is increased to 3 μm. It reduces to 1 dB when the radius is 5 μm. The TDLSPPW has an increased propagation length, a subwavelength waveguide width and a low bending loss. They can be applied to achieve many kinds of high-density devices such as Mach–Zehnder interferometers, ring oscillators, directional couplers etc.
Fig. 7
(a) The fitting of propagation lengths from the measured leakage radiation optical images. The insets show the optical images for TDLSPWW and DLSPPW. (b) The fitted propagation lengths of TDLSPPW and DLSPPW at different wavelengths. (c) The measured 90∘ bending loss for different bending radii in the TDLSPPWs. The leakage radiation optical images are shown in the insets

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: We demonstrated a strong mode confinement in the low-index dielectric region by using a high-index/low-index/metal configuration. The propagation properties of the two-layer dielectric-loaded SPP waveguide were characterized by using a vector finite-difference method. In the experiments, we measured the propagation length of SPP waveguides from visible to infrared light by using the near-field excitation method and leakage radiation measurement. Under the same waveguide dimension and propagation index, the averaged propagation length of the SPP mode in the TDLSPPW is about 1.6 times longer than conventional DLSPPWs. The 90∘ waveguide bend showed only a 1.7 dB loss for a bending radius of 3 μm. The modification of the dielectric layer by high-index/low-index layers can substantially increase the propagation length and optical confinement. Moreover, the simple fabrication approach can be easily applied for active plasmonic components by using thermo-optical or electro-optical materials for the low-index dielectric layer.
